summary: This document is an email chain between prosecutors and defense attorneys in the US v. Maxwell case regarding logistics for the defense team to review physical and electronic evidence. It details negotiations over where evidence will be made available (Bronx warehouse vs. 500 Pearl Street courthouse), what items can be photographed, and the handling of 'Highly Confidential' materials, including thousands of nude/partially nude images seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C., representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She is the primary defense correspondent in the email chain, negotiating evidence review logistics with the prosecution.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on the email chain regarding evidence review logistics.

persons.name: Christian R Everdell
persons.context: Defense attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP, copied on the email chain regarding evidence review logistics for Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Bobbi C Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on the email chain regarding evidence review logistics.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the case (US v. Maxwell - 20 Cr. 330). The emails discuss arrangements for her to be produced to the courthouse to review evidence with her defense team.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the source of seized evidence, including electronic devices, images, and videos from his residences. The evidence includes nude/partially nude images seized from his devices.

connections.description: Menninger is a defense attorney representing Maxwell, as shown by her negotiating evidence review logistics on Maxwell's behalf.
Pagliuca is defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on all evidence review correspondence.
Everdell is defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on all evidence review correspondence.
Sternheim is defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on all evidence review correspondence.
Evidence seized from Epstein's residences is central to the case against Maxwell, indicating their prior association.
They are opposing counsel negotiating the terms of evidence review in the criminal case.

events.title: Scheduled Bronx Warehouse Evidence Review
events.description: Defense team (attorney, investigator, paralegal) scheduled to review and photograph 'excluded from transportation' evidence items at the FBI's Bronx warehouse.

events.title: Scheduled Courthouse Evidence Review Begins
events.description: Start date for the defense team and Ghislaine Maxwell to review evidence transported to the 500 Pearl Street courthouse, scheduled from 9:30am to 4:30pm daily.

events.title: Government Production of Images/Videos
events.description: The government produced images and videos seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices, with a cover letter noting that nude/partially nude images were designated 'Highly Confidential' and would be made available for defense review upon request.

events.title: Discovery Production Including Evidence Index
events.description: Government produced discovery including an index of physical items in FBI custody from the FBI-Miami office's investigation of Epstein and search warrant returns from the 2019 searches of Epstein's residences.

locations: 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY (courthouse for evidence review)
1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY (Southern District of New York U.S. Attorney's Office)
26 Federal Plaza, New York, NY (location of some evidence items)
keyFacts: The defense sought to review all physical and electronic evidence, including thousands of 'Highly Confidential' nude/partially nude images seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices.
Logistical negotiations centered on transporting evidence from an FBI warehouse in the Bronx to the 500 Pearl Street courthouse, with some 'bulky' or 'fragile' items to be reviewed at the warehouse.
The government revealed the existence of approximately 2,100 electronic images/videos from Epstein's devices and 7 hard-copy nude images that had not been previously provided to the defense.
Evidence review at the courthouse was scheduled to begin on April 13, 2021, with Ghislaine Maxwell produced daily by the Marshals.
The defense raised specific issues about evidence, including shredded paper, missing items, stripped metadata, and the format of recordings from 2007.
